A paradoxical effect (e.g., decreasing bactericidal activity with increasing antibiotic concentration) with amoxicillin has also been demonstrated with two strains of nontoxigenic C. diphtheriae isolated from patients with endocarditis (248). The investigators suggested that poor bactericidal activity of penicillins at high doses may contribute to poor outcomes when penicillins are included in the therapeutic regimen for C. diphtheriae endocarditis (248). Monoresistance to the folate pathway inhibitors trimethoprim, sulfamethoxazole, and cotrimoxazole has been reported, most recently in a C. diphtheriae biovar mitis strain isolated from a patient in Mayotte (249).

Growth characteristics among theCorynebacterium spp. may vary, and previous studies have used a variety of methods, media, and incubation conditions for antimicrobial susceptibility testing. CLSI recommends BMD with CA-MHB-LHB and incubation in ambient air (Table 3). Some strains grow satisfactorily after 24 h of incubation, but others require 48 h of incubation for sufficient growth. The 48-h incubation is particularly important for detecting resistance to β-lactams, and it is recommended, if growth is not satisfactory or if an isolate appears susceptible to β-lactams at 24 h, that the test be reincubated and final results read after 48 h of incubation (6). Other antimicrobials can be reported after 24 h, provided sufficient growth is observed. Currently, disk diffusion testing of Corynebacterium spp. is not recommended by CLSI. EUCAST provides both MIC and zone diameter interpretative criteria for Corynebacterium spp. (6). For disk diffusion, MH-F agar is recommended, and plates can be read initially at 16 to 20 h or 40 to 44 h if growth is insufficient at the initial read. Several investigators have used Etest satisfactorily for testing Corynebacterium spp. (235, 245, 250). However, a recent study evaluating 421 human and veterinary isolates of C. diphtheriae and C. ulcerans found that Etest underestimated MICs of penicillin and overestimated MICs of clindamycin (251).

Testing and reporting recommendations in CLSI M45-A3 are applicable to other coryneforms and include the generaArcanobacterium, Arthrobacter, Brevibacterium, Cellulomonas, Cellulosimicrobium, Dermabacter, Leifsonia, Microbacterium, Oerskovia, Rothia (excluding Rothia mucilaginosa), Trueperella, and Turicella (6). Scarce data are available in the literature regarding antimicrobial susceptibility of these organisms, and methods used vary between studies. However, macrolide resistance has been noted for isolates of Brevibacterium, Dermabacter, and Turicella and fluoroquinolone resistance for Brevibacterium and Dermabacter (237). Arcanobacterium haemolyticum appears to be universally resistant to TMP-SMX (252), while some isolates may display tetracycline resistance (253). A. haemolyticum isolates are reportedly susceptible to other agents that might be considered for treatment, but clinical failure has been reported with penicillin (252). One study has reported A. haemolyticum and Oerskovia turbata harboring the vanA gene on a plasmid; both isolates were vancomycin resistant (254). A study of 50 clinical isolates of Microbacterium spp. demonstrated variable susceptibility profiles, but notably only 56% of isolates were susceptible to ciprofloxacin; one isolate, a Microbacterium resistens, was resistant to vancomycin, which is typical for this species (255). Turicella otitidis is susceptible to most β-lactams, ciprofloxacin, rifampin, tetracyclines, and gentamicin, but significant resistance to macrolides and lincosamides in association with 23S rRNA mutations has been reported (256, 257). Susceptibility testing of Corynebacterium spp. and other coryneforms is warranted when the organisms are isolated from normally sterile sites.

sect2.title: ERYSIPELOTHRIX RHUSIOPATHIAE
sect2.para: Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is intrinsically vancomycin resistant. Other agents that have little to no activity against isolates of this species are aminoglycosides and TMP-SMX. Antimicrobial susceptibility studies of isolates from a number of sources have shown all isolates of E. rhusiopathiae to be susceptible to penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems, and fluoroquinolones (258–260). Case reports document single cases of penicillin resistance (261, 262). Resistance to clindamycin, erythromycin, and tetracycline does occur. The tet(M) gene found in tetracycline-resistant E. rhusiopathiae is 99% similar to that in Enterococcus faecalis. Resistance to macrolides is related to expression of the plasmid-borne erm(T) gene or an erm(A)-like gene (263, 264). A recent study of E. rhusiopathiae isolated from cases of swine erysipelas is the most up-to-date survey of antimicrobial resistance in this organism by reference CLSI methods. This study demonstrated 51% resistance to tetracycline, 53% to erythromycin, 70% to clindamycin, 92% to ciprofloxacin, and 0% to meropenem and cefotaxime among 120 isolates (264).

Isolates ofE. rhusiopathiae are fastidious, so CA-MHB-LHB is recommended for BMD MIC testing (6). When the test organism is isolated from sterile sites, laboratories should primarily test ampicillin or penicillin (6).

sect2.title: GEMELLA
sect2.para: Limited data in the literature demonstrateGemella spp. to be susceptible to many antimicrobial agents, including penicillin. CLSI breakpoints for Gemella spp. are based on data from 45 isolates tested at three laboratories and demonstrated 95% susceptibility to penicillin and ceftriaxone, 98% to meropenem, and 96% to vancomycin. In contrast, only 56% of isolates were susceptible to erythromycin (265). Intrinsic resistance to TMP-SMX is reported (266). Gemella spp. demonstrate in vitro synergy between penicillin or vancomycin plus gentamicin or streptomycin (266).

Isolates ofGemella are fastidious, and CA-MHB-LHB is recommended for BMD MIC testing (6). Isolates may require up to 48 h of incubation before sufficient growth is evident. Gemella morbillorum may display improved growth using CLSI anaerobic test conditions (i.e., agar dilution using brucella agar supplemented with 5% sheep blood, hemin, and vitamin K1, incubated anaerobically or in 5% CO2) (267, 268). CLSI provides breakpoints for penicillin, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, meropenem, vancomycin, erythromycin, levofloxacin, and clindamycin. When test organisms are isolated from sterile sites, laboratories should primarily test penicillin, cefotaxime or ceftriaxone, and vancomycin (6).

sect2.title: HACEK GROUP
sect2.para: There are limited antimicrobial susceptibility test data on the HACEK organisms (i.e.,Aggregatibacter [formerly the aphrophilus group of Haemophilus and Actinobacillus], Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella spp.) in part because these organisms are infrequently encountered and often difficult to grow.

Members of HACEK are susceptible to extended-spectrum cephalosporins and fluoroquinolones and are often susceptiblein vitro to ampicillin and penicillin (57, 269, 270), although isolates of Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella spp. can produce β-lactamase (270). Coburn and colleagues noted that 22.9% of 68 isolates belonging to the HACEK group were nonsusceptible to penicillin, but 95.8% of isolates remained susceptible to ampicillin, and all but two isolates were susceptible to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. One E. corrodens isolate tested resistant to penicillin and ampicillin, but tested negative for the presence of β-lactamase by the Cefinase disk method (270). American Heart Association recommendations for treatment of patients with endocarditis caused by HACEK organisms suggest that HACEK organisms should be considered ampicillin resistant, unless sufficient growth is present to obtain susceptibility data (178).

TheKingella kingae β-lactamase is encoded by the blaTEM-1 gene, which can be located on the chromosome or a plasmid (271), and is limited to distinct clones of K. kingae. blaTEM-1 was found in 20% of 15 United States isolates recovered from invasive infections, in 28.6% of 14 isolates recovered in Iceland, but in only 1.1% of 190 isolates recovered in Israel and 0% of isolates recovered in Canada (n = 24), France (n = 56), and Spain (n = 32) (272). Among a collection of 159 K. kingae evaluated by EUCAST when establishing clinical breakpoints for this species, β-lactamase was detected in 41 (26%) (273). Isolates with β-lactamase were also resistant to TMP-SMX in this study. K. kingae clindamycin MICs range from 0.5 to >2 μg/ml, which led EUCAST to designate these isolates as intrinsically resistant to clindamycin (273), a challenge in regions where empiric regimens for pediatric skeletal infections include clindamycin. In the EUCAST study, 8% of isolates were resistant to tetracycline and, as is the case for other bacteria, tetracycline susceptibility could be used to predict doxycycline susceptibility.

BMD with CA-MHB-LHB can be used for testing HACEK organisms. Some isolates may require 48 h of incubation to obtain adequate growth as evidenced by substantial turbidity in the positive growth control well. Coburn et al. demonstrated that 104 (59.8%) of 174 HACEK isolates failed to grow in CA-MHB-LHB. In particular, poor growth was noted forA. actinomycetemcomitans (83.3% of isolates), A. aphrophilus (60.7%), and C. hominis (60%) (270). This study led CLSI to evaluate alternative test media, including HTM or brucella broth with vitamin K, hemin, and 5% lysed horse blood. Aggregatibacter spp. appear to grow better in HTM broth and Eikenella spp. in brucella broth supplemented with vitamin K1, hemin, and 5% LHB (6). EUCAST disk and MIC breakpoints are available for K. kingae alone using MH-F test media (2). Susceptibility testing may be warranted for isolates from normally sterile sites, and β-lactamase testing should be performed on HACEK isolates (6), although laboratories should be aware that not all ampicillin-resistant isolates may be detected by this testing (270).

sect1.title: Incidence of Resistance
sect1.para: H. pylori is intrinsically resistant to glycopeptides, polymyxins, nalidixic acid, trimethoprim, and sulfonamides. H. pylori is treated with triple therapy consisting of metronidazole, clarithromycin, and a fluoroquinolone. The rates of resistance for H. pylori vary considerably for these first-line agents. A summary of surveillance studies concluded that global clarithromycin resistance rates are >15%, above the threshold where either alternative empiric regimens or routine clarithromycin susceptibility testing is recommended (274, 275). Global levofloxacin resistance rates are 15 to 20%, and metronidazole resistance rates are 45 to 55%. The exception to this trend is H. pylori isolates recovered in studies conducted in China, where metronidazole resistance is >75% (276, 277). In 2017, the World Health Organization designated clarithromycin-resistant H. pylori a high priority for antibiotic research and development. Surveillance conducted in Europe in 2018 demonstrated that both clarithromycin and levofloxacin resistance rates were associated with community consumption rates of macrolides and fluoroquinolones, respectively (276, 278). In contrast to first-line agents, resistance to amoxicillin or tetracycline is ≤10% globally, with the exception of the eastern Mediterranean region, where amoxicillin resistance is estimated at 14% (277). On a per-patient level, prior treatment with metronidazole and clarithromycin is associated with increased risk of resistance to these drugs (277, 279).

sect1.title: Reference Test Method
sect1.para: CLSI describes an agar dilution MIC method for testingH. pylori. The test medium is MHA supplemented with 5% (vol/vol) aged (>2-week-old) sheep blood. Aged sheep blood provides superior growth, and fresh sheep blood should not be used. The inoculum is prepared from 72-h-old growth on a blood agar plate to obtain a final concentration of bacteria approximating 105 CFU/spot. Incubation is for 3 days at 35°C in a microaerobic atmosphere produced by a gas-generating system typically used for Campylobacter. H. pylori ATCC 43504 has been designated as a QC strain, and currently there are only CLSI interpretive criteria for clarithromycin. Other antimicrobial agents that have been studied and for which there are CLSI QC ranges include amoxicillin, metronidazole, telithromycin, and tetracycline (6). EUCAST has defined MIC interpretive criteria, based on epidemiological cutoff values, for metronidazole, clarithromycin, amoxicillin, levofloxacin, tetracycline, and rifampin (2). Although there are currently no CLSI interpretive criteria for metronidazole, many investigators use the EUCAST cutoff of >8 mg/liter for resistance. CLSI cautions, in the M45-A3, that testing of metronidazole under the CLSI reference MIC method for H. pylori does not reliably predict treatment outcome, and that testing of metronidazole is not recommended (6). The European Helicobacter pylori Study Group has published an agar dilution method that is similar to the CLSI method; however, they recommend horse blood-supplemented MHA and a higher inoculum (280). Although there is no standard method for disk diffusion testing, Grignon et al. have demonstrated that this method is reliable for testing clarithromycin (281), the drug that is usually of greatest interest.

sect1.title: Commercial Test Methods
sect1.para: No commercial methods are FDA cleared for antimicrobial susceptibility testing ofH. pylori, but several investigators have examined the performance of Etest. Drawing a conclusion for the performance of Etest across studies is complicated by the fact that significant differences in methods, including media types, inoculum concentration, and incubation conditions, exist (280, 282, 283). The Etest manufacturer recommends alternative incubation conditions for H. pylori when testing metronidazole, for example, incubation in an anaerobic environment for 24 h, followed by 48 h of incubation in a microaerophilic environment (Etest Package Insert 2012, bioMérieux). Preincubation in an anaerobic environment was shown to significantly improve Etest agreement with agar dilution (284), although MHA supplemented with 5% horse blood, as opposed to aged sheep blood, was used for agar dilution in this study. A recent multicenter study using standardized test methodology demonstrated that Etest performed well for evaluation of clarithromycin, ciprofloxacin, and clindamycin (285).

sect1.title: Molecular Approaches to Susceptibility Testing of H. pylori
sect1.para: H. pylori resistance mechanisms for clarithromycin and fluoroquinolones are relatively well known. For the former, resistance is mainly associated with point mutations to domain V of the 23S rRNA gene, namely at positions A2146 and A2147. Fluoroquinolone resistance is associated with mutation to the QRDR of gyrA at codons 87 and 91, either alone or in combination with mutation to gyrB (286). With this knowledge, genotypic methods are increasingly used as a surrogate for phenotypic susceptibility testing, particularly for clarithromycin (287, 288). A recent study conducted in Rhode Island evaluated H. pylori resistance determinants using a whole-genome sequencing approach. The investigators found that patients with predicted clarithromycin-resistant H. pylori had a significantly higher rate of eradication failure (56%) compared to eradication success (14%) when a clarithromycin-containing regimen was prescribed. Similarly, Kim et al. conducted a retrospective study of 464 patients with H. pylori infection and found that bismuth-quadruple therapy was superior to standard triple therapy for patients with PCR-predicted clarithromycin resistance (i.e., A2143 or A2142 mutations) (288). In contrast, metronidazole resistance was not different between patients with eradication failures and successes (289). This factor may be due to the relatively more complex array of resistance pathways associated with metronidazole resistance in H. pylori (286). At present, no commercial tests are available for molecular detection of H. pylori resistance, but such testing is available at some reference laboratories.

sect1.title: Strategies for Testing and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Growth requirements and complex antimicrobial susceptibility testing recommendations for only a limited number of drugs make testing ofH. pylori impractical for the routine clinical laboratory. However, because of the significant resistance noted for metronidazole and clarithromycin, testing is recommended for patients with ≥2 treatment failures, in which case a reliable reference laboratory should be used. Resistant isolates may not be evenly distributed throughout the stomach, and susceptibility results for isolates from a single biopsy may not be representative of the entire population (290, 291). A recent United States consensus document recommended routine evaluation of amoxicillin, clarithromycin, levofloxacin, metronidazole, and tetracycline when susceptibility testing is performed (292).

sect2.title: LACTOBACILLUS, PEDIOCOCCUS, AND LEUCONOSTOC SPECIES
sect2.para: Pediococcus spp., Leuconostoc spp., and most Lactobacillus spp. are intrinsically vancomycin resistant. Lactobacillus gasseri, Lactobacillus delbrueckii, and Lactobacillus acidophilus may be vancomycin susceptible (293–296).

Lactobacillus spp. are generally resistant to metronidazole, aminoglycosides, and ciprofloxacin (297), but their MICs for penicillin and cephalosporins can vary (293–296, 298). In a study of 85 blood isolates, MICs ranged from 0.06 μg/ml to 4 μg/ml for penicillin and from 0.25 to ≥256 μg/ml for ceftriaxone, with Lactobacillus casei and Lactobacillus rhamnosus being among the species with the least susceptibility to these agents (296). L. acidophilus is susceptible to penicillin and vancomycin, whereas L. rhamnosus and L. casei are resistant (297). Fluoroquinolones have poor activity against most Lactobacillus spp. (293, 294, 296, 298).

Leuconostoc spp. are usually susceptible to clindamycin and erythromycin, and penicillin MICs are generally less than 0.5 μg/ml (298–300). Ceftriaxone MICs have been shown to vary from 1 to >128 μg/ml, and elevated imipenem MICs (>0.5 μg/ml) and meropenem MICs (>8 μg/ml) have been described (298–300). Leuconostoc spp. daptomycin MICs are low (<0.5 μg/ml), and linezolid MICs range from 2 to 8.0 μg/ml (301).

Pediococcus spp. are generally susceptible to clindamycin and erythromycin (295, 298, 299, 302), but resistant strains have been reported (299). A penicillin MIC90 of 0.5 μg/ml was reported for 49 isolates (295), but penicillin MICs as high as 2 μg/ml have been noted (299). MICs for ceftriaxone are generally ≥16 μg/ml; however, most isolates are very susceptible to imipenem (MICs of <0.25 μg/ml) (298, 299). Pediococcus spp. are resistant to ciprofloxacin (298, 299, 302). Gentamicin, which would only be used in combination therapy, has variable activity against isolates of all three genera (295, 298, 299, 302).

The medium recommended by CLSI for BMD testing ofLactobacillus spp., Pediococcus spp., and Leuconostoc spp. is CA-MHB-LHB (Table 3) (6). EUCAST provides MIC interpretative criteria for only Lactobacillus spp. as part of the Gram-positive anaerobes. Some have performed susceptibility testing by agar dilution using either unsupplemented MHA or BMHA (298). If testing by agar dilution, incubation in 5% CO2 may be necessary to achieve sufficient growth.

sect2.title: LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES
sect2.para: Clinical isolates ofL. monocytogenes remain susceptible to the drugs of choice, including ampicillin (or penicillin) and TMP-SMX. With the exception of occasional resistance to tetracyclines, expressed by a tetM or tetS gene, and ciprofloxacin, mediated by active efflux (303), L. monocytogenes is typically susceptible in vitro to other agents active against Gram-positive bacteria, including vancomycin and macrolides (303, 304). Daptomycin MICs are elevated (MIC90, 4 μg/ml) and linezolid MICs range from 1 to 2 μg/ml (304). Although L. monocytogenes may appear susceptible to cephalosporins in vitro, these agents are not effective clinically.

Antimicrobial susceptibilities of 2,862L. monocytogenes from national food surveillance conducted in China between 2012 and 2015 confirmed universal susceptibility to ampicillin, although 28 isolates were resitant to TMP-SMX (1%) (305). All isolates were susceptible to ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, meropenem, and vancomycin. Sporadic isolates were resistant to tetracycline (8.7%), erythromycin (2.2%), and chloramphenicol (0.8%). Whole-genome sequencing confirmed that TMP-SMX resistance was associated with the presence of a dihydrofolate reductase drfG gene. It is suggested that this resistance mechanism was acquired via mobile genetic elements from S. pyogenes (305). Other studies have recently reported resistance to one or more clinically relevant antibiotics in L. monocytogenes isolated from food and food processing environments (306). Overexpression of efflux systems has been shown to be selected for by the disinfectant benzalkonium chloride, used in commercial food production facilities (307). A recent study documented an increasing rate of unfavorable outcomes among adults with listerial meningitis in the Netherlands. These cases were associated with the emergence of the ST6 strain of L. monocytogenes, which displays reduced susceptibility to these disinfectants. ST6 strains harbor the multidrug efflux protein Emr, which is associated with quaternary ammonia tolerance, and also elevated MICs for gentamicin (0.125 mg/liter) and amoxicillin (0.25 mg/liter) as compared to wild-type strains (308).

Listeria infections are generally treated empirically, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing is usually not necessary. Susceptibility-only breakpoints (<2 μg/ml) are listed for ampicillin and penicillin in CLSI guidelines (6). EUCAST breakpoints differ slightly, with an MIC of <1 mg/liter defining susceptibility for ampicillin and penicillin and >1 mg/liter defining resistance (2). In addition, the CLSI TMP-SMX breakpoint for susceptibility is ≤0.25 μg/ml, whereas EUCAST defines a much lower cutoff of ≤0.06 μg/ml. CLSI recommends using CA-MHB-LHB for MIC testing, and EUCAST recommends MH-F. In addition to MIC breakpoints, EUCAST publishes disk diffusion interpretations for penicillin, ampicillin, meropenem, erythromycin, and TMP-SMX (2). It is important to remember that cephalosporins should not be tested or reported for L. monocytogenes because some isolates may, for example, have ceftriaxone MICs as low as 8 μg/ml, which could suggest false susceptibility (309). Because cephalosporins are frequently used empirically for the treatment of meningitis, the laboratory should quickly communicate smear or culture findings suspicious for Listeria whenever they occur.

sect2.title: MICROCOCCUS
sect2.para: Limited data in the literature demonstrateMicrococcus spp. to be susceptible to many antimicrobial agents, although resistance to β-lactams and erythromycin has been reported (310, 311). CLSI recently developed breakpoints for Micrococcus spp., which can be applied to Kocuria, Nesterenkonia, Dermacoccus, and Kytococcus spp.

Isolates ofMicrococcus can be tested in routine CA-MHB in ambient air (6). CLSI provides breakpoints for penicillin, vancomycin, erythromycin, and clindamycin. When test strains are isolated from sterile sites, laboratories should primarily test penicillin and vancomycin (6).

sect2.title: MORAXELLA CATARRHALIS
sect2.para: M. catarrhalis has maintained a high degree of susceptibility to all antimicrobial agents that might be used to treat associated infections, with the exception of penicillinase-susceptible penicillins. More than 90% of M. catarrhalis isolates produce β-lactamase and are resistant to amoxicillin, ampicillin, and penicillin (19, 81, 82, 86, 312). These isolates remain susceptible to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, which is often prescribed for M. catarrhalis infections.

Most clinical isolates produce one of two types of β-lactamase: BRO-1 or BRO-2 (312, 313). Both enzymes are encoded by chromosomal genes and are phenotypically identical and membrane associated. BRO-1-producing strains are more prevalent than BRO-2-producing strains, and ampicillin and penicillin MICs for BRO-1 are often higher (e.g., ≥4 μg/ml) than those for BRO-2 strains (e.g., <0.5 μg/ml) (312–314). The clinical significance in response to β-lactamase-labile penicillins of BRO-2 strains is questionable. Resistance rates for TMP-SMX are less than 5% in most studies (81, 82, 312, 313), although investigators reported that 18.5% of 314 isolates from 11 hospitals in Taiwan (312) and 11.4% of 140 isolates from 19 hospitals in China were resistant to TMP-SMX (72). A recent study from two county hospitals in China reported a resistance rate of 19.1% using EUCAST clinical breakpoints, and 10.1% using CLSI clinical breakpoints (315). Resistance to macrolides and tetracyclines is generally low (<1% from isolates in the Western Hemisphere in 2009–2011) (75, 83, 86, 312). In the Asia-Pacific region, clarithromycin and tetracycline resistances were 7.6% and 3.2%, respectively, and the majority of nonsusceptible isolates were from China (316). A recent study from China reported tetracycline resistance at 16.4% (72).

Only the chromogenic cephalosporin method has reliably detected the β-lactamases produced byM. catarrhalis (317). Routine β-lactamase testing may not be necessary because of the high incidence of β-lactamase-positive strains. Nevertheless, some advocate reporting of β-lactamase results to highlight the fact that this pathogen is generally unresponsive to some agents commonly prescribed for the treatment of respiratory tract infections (e.g., amoxicillin). MIC testing in the absence of β-lactamase testing can be problematic, as there is some overlap in ampicillin and amoxicillin MICs in β-lactamase-positive and -negative strains. Since M. catarrhalis typically responds to the drugs of choice, testing beyond the β-lactamase test is rarely indicated. CLSI document M45-A3 addresses MIC testing of M. catarrhalis (6). Recommendations for disk diffusion testing of amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, azithromycin, clarithromycin, erythromycin, tetracycline, and TMP-SMX using MHA and incubation in 5% CO2 are included in CLSI M45-A3 (Table 3). EUCAST offers MIC and zone diameter breakpoints for M. catarrhalis. In contrast to CLSI guidelines, MIC breakpoints (≤1 μg/ml) are provided by EUCAST. In addition, the nalidixic acid disk diffusion test can be used to screen for fluoroquinolone resistance, and isolates that are susceptible to nalidixic acid can be considered susceptible to ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, and ofloxacin (6).

sect2.title: PASTEURELLA SPECIES
sect2.para: Human isolates ofPasteurella spp. are generally susceptible to penicillin, with MICs of ≤0.5 μg/ml (318, 319). Sporadic reports of human infections with β-lactamase-producing isolates demonstrated positive reactions with a nitrocefin-impregnated disk test, amoxicillin MICs of 8 to 64 μg/ml, and amoxicillin-clavulanic acid MICs of 0.25 to 1 μg/ml (320). Pasteurella spp. are generally very susceptible to antimicrobial agents commonly used for the treatment of acute bacterial skin and skin structure infections: a recent study documented very low MICs to cefazolin, ceftriaxone, ampicillin-sulbactam, ertapenem, azithromycin, doxycycline, and TMP-SMX among 156 Pasteurella spp. isolated from patients with animal bite wounds (321). No studies have documented resistance among clinical isolates for parenteral cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones, tetracyclines, chloramphenicol, or TMP-SMX (318, 319). Resistance to erythromycin is fairly widespread, with reported MICs of 0.5 to 4 μg/ml (318), and there is at least one report of erythromycin failure with subsequent meningitis in a cat bite victim (322).

BMD and disk diffusion methods are described by CLSI for testingPasteurella spp. (Table 3). Similarly, EUCAST also provides guidance for MIC and disk diffusion testing. Due to the absence of nonsusceptible strains, CLSI only provides susceptible interpretive criteria for agents that might be tested, with the exception of erythromycin. In contrast, EUCAST provides resistant interpretative criteria for Pasteurella spp. and infers ampicillin and amoxicillin susceptibility based on the penicillin result. In addition, the nalidixic acid disk diffusion test can also be set up to screen for fluoroquinolone susceptibility, as described for M. catarrhalis (322).

Susceptibility testing may be warranted for isolates from normally sterile sites, and β-lactamase testing should be performed on these isolates as well as those from respiratory sources (6). Testing of isolates recovered from bite wounds is not necessary, as they are generally treated empirically with agents that would cover a variety of organisms likely to be implicated in the infection (e.g., amoxicillin-clavulanic acid).

sect2.title: ROTHIA MUCILAGINOSA
sect2.para: Limited data exist in the literature regarding susceptibility ofR. mucilaginosa. Resistance to β-lactams, clindamycin, erythromycin, and fluoroquinolones has been reported (310). A recent report from the Mayo Clinic documented difficulty in testing R. mucilaginosa on MHA-LHB by agar dilution, with only a quarter of isolates demonstrating sufficient growth. Of those tested, all were susceptible to penicillin (9/9) and vancomycin (13/13) (323).

Isolates ofR. mucilaginosa are generally fastidious, and testing must be performed on blood-supplemented media to obtain adequate growth. CLSI recommends CA-MHB-LHB (6). CLSI provides breakpoints for penicillin, vancomycin, erythromycin, clindamycin, levofloxacin, and TMP-SMX. When test organisms are isolated from sterile sites, laboratories should primarily test penicillin and vancomycin (6).

sect2.title: VIBRIO SPECIES
sect2.para: BothVibrio cholerae and the non-cholera Vibrio spp. are often susceptible to most antimicrobial agents, including newer cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, and tetracyclines; however, resistance to one or more of these can occur (324).

Historically, resistance inV. cholerae emerged via spontaneous mutation to the targets of individual antimicrobial agents. However, more recently, antimicrobial resistance has been facilitated by horizontal gene transfer (325). Multidrug-resistant V. cholerae has been attributed to the presence of genetic elements harbored on a R plasmid (326), whereas the integrating conjugative resistance element SXT, which encodes resistance to trimethoprim, sulfamethoxazole, and streptomycin, has been observed among V. cholerae strains from multiple cholera outbreaks (324, 327). Antimicrobial susceptibility testing of 550 V. cholerae El Tor biotype O1 organisms isolated in China between 1961 and 2010 documented significant increases in resistance to TMP-SMX (from 0 to 38.5%), tetracycline (from 0 to 89%), and nalidixic acid (0 to 45.9%) (328). In contrast, a study of 340 V. cholerae O139 isolates in China between 1993 and 2009 displayed high rates of resistance to nalidixic acid (83.1%), tetracycline (83.4%), azithromycin (50.3%), and TMP-SMX (90.7%) (329). A V. cholerae El Tor Ogawa strain was isolated from a child in India that harbored both the blaDHA and blaNDM-1 genes, with resistance to third-generation cephalosporins detected by Etest and agar dilution (330).

When a double-blind randomized study was conducted to compare the equivalence of azithromycin and ciprofloxacin, 78% of 97 patients had a bacteriologic cure with azithromycin, compared with only 10% of 98 patients who received ciprofloxacin. The 168 isolates from these patients were susceptible to both azithromycin and ciprofloxacin when tested by disk diffusion and Etest, but the median ciprofloxacin MIC for 91V. cholerae serogroup O1 isolates was 0.25 μg/ml, which is significantly above the wild-type MIC (331). The elevated MICs and poor outcomes suggest the possibility of a resistance mechanism not detectable when the CLSI breakpoint of ≤1 μg/ml is used to define ciprofloxacin susceptibility. Isolates from the 2010 Haitian V. cholerae O1 outbreak were found to have reduced susceptibility to ciprofloxacin (0.25 to 1.0 μg/ml), which was associated with mutation to the QRDR region of gyrA and parC (332). Recently published EUCAST breakpoints for Vibrio indicate ≤0.25 mg/liter as the cutoff for susceptibility to ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin.

Since 2009, the CDC has been annually tracking antimicrobial resistance inVibrio spp. other than V. cholerae. In each year studied, Vibrio parahaemolyticus represented the largest number of isolates submitted to the CDC for testing, followed by Vibrio alginolyticus and Vibrio vulnificus. Fewer than 50 isolates of other species were submitted for testing. In 2019, 96% of V. alginolyticus were resistant to ampicillin, in contrast to 49% of V. parahaemolyticus and 4% of V. vulnificus. No isolates of Vibrio spp. tested were resistant to ceftazidime or quinolones, and 0.3% of isolates were resistant to TMP-SMX and tetracycline (223).

Antibiotics (primarily azithromycin or ciprofloxacin) are given to patients with cholera after fluid restoration and vomiting has ceased. These have been shown to reduce the total volume of stool passed and to shorten the duration of fecal excretion ofV. cholerae. Although the non-cholera Vibrio spp. cause diarrheal disease, otherwise healthy individuals with diarrhea due to these bacteria usually recover spontaneously without treatment. When Vibrio spp. are isolated from sources associated with serious infections, antimicrobial susceptibility testing is warranted. Both CLSI and EUCAST suggest BMD or disk diffusion using methodologies similar to those for testing Enterobacterales. For testing of the halophilic Vibrio spp., some have suggested use of MHA containing 1% NaCl. However, CLSI recommends preparation of the inoculum suspension in 0.85% NaCl solution for both disk diffusion and BMD MIC testing with MHA or CA-MHB (both without NaCl supplementation), respectively (6).

sect2.title: CONCLUSION
sect2.para: With the exception of serious streptococcal infections, extraintestinalAeromonas or Vibrio infections, and device-associated coryneform infections, infections caused by many of the fastidious bacteria discussed in this chapter are treated empirically, as these bacteria are often susceptible to the drugs of choice. Consequently, susceptibility testing is infrequently needed for many of these organisms. In certain circumstances, testing may be warranted, such as when there appears to be clinical failure, patient intolerance to the drug(s) of choice, or serious infections for which there are limited appropriate drugs that might be prescribed. Additionally, susceptibility testing may aid in species identification (e.g., differentiating C. jeikeium from other Corynebacterium spp.). If a caregiver seems unsure about requesting antimicrobial susceptibility testing on a fastidious organism, he/she should be encouraged to seek assistance from an infectious diseases clinician or pharmacist.

Requests for susceptibility testing of fastidious bacteria are often for isolates associated with serious infections, and MIC results are likely to be more useful than qualitative results. The disk diffusion test should be used only for bacteria for which there are CLSI or EUCAST interpretive criteria. It is important for laboratory workers to maintain an awareness of the methods available for testing fastidious bacteria and their strengths and limitations. If testing must be performed, it should be done by a laboratory that has validated the susceptibility methods used for the organism to be tested.
